title: 113_hr5758
content: The "Financial Institution Customer Protection Act of 2014" requires specific procedures for deposit account termination requests and orders. The "Financial Institution Customer Protection Act of 2014" mandates that Federal banking agencies cannot request a depository institution to terminate a customer account without a material reason, excluding reputation risk. If a customer is believed to pose a national security threat, such as involvement in terrorist financing, this belief satisfies the materiality requirement. The "Financial Institution Customer Protection Act of 2014" requires Federal banking agencies to define "reputation risk" within 60 days of enactment. If an agency requests a depository institution to terminate a customer account, they must provide a written justification, including specific laws or regulations. The "Financial Institution Customer Protection Act of 2014" mandates Federal banking agencies to define "reputation risk" within 60 days. If an agency requests an account termination, a written justification with specific laws or regulations must be provided. Customer notice is not required, except in cases of national security. The "Financial Institution Customer Protection Act of 2014" requires Federal banking agencies to define "reputation risk" within 60 days. If an agency orders a customer account termination based on national security concerns, the customer may not be informed of the justification. The appropriate Federal banking agency must report annually to Congress the number of accounts terminated and the legal basis for such actions. The term "depository institution" is defined by the appropriate Federal banking agency and the National Credit Union Administration for insured credit unions. SEC. 3. AMENDMENTS TO THE FINANCIAL INSTITUTIONS REFORM, RECOVERY, AND ENFORCEMENT ACT OF 1989. Section 951 of the Financial Institutions Reform, Recovery, and Enforcement Act of 1989 is amended to allow the Attorney General to conduct investigations, summon witnesses, and request the production of relevant records with a court order. The Attorney General can issue a subpoena for information or testimony if there are reasonable grounds to believe it is relevant for conducting an investigation under this section.
